/> *The report's scope is limited to the abuse of detainees directly in CIA custody and does not include detainees tortured at the behest of the CIA after being [[extraordinary rendition|extraordinarily rendered]].<ref name="Slate Rendition">{{cite web |url=http://www.slate.com/articles/news_and_politics/politics/2014/12/senate_torture_report_s_unnamed_victims_the_cia_had_hundreds_or_thousands.html |title=Outsourced Terror: The horrific stories of CIA-sponsored torture that aren't in the Senate report |last1=Watt |first1=Steven |date=December 19, 2014 |website=[[Slate (magazine)]] |access-date=February 11, 2015}}</ref> *In 2008, 85% of the Rendition, Detention and Interrogation Group consisted of outside contractors.<ref name=outsourced>{{cite news |last=Molloy |first=Tim |date=2014-12-11 |title=How the CIA Outsourced Torture |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/iraq-war-on-terror/how-the-cia-outsourced-torture/ |newspaper=[[PBS]] |access-date=2015-05-19 }}</ref>
=== Contractors === Contractors that developed the "enhanced interrogation techniques" ([[Bruce Jessen|John "Bruce" Jessen]] and [[James Elmer Mitchell|James Mitchell]]), received {{USD}}81 million for their services, out of an original contract worth more than {{USD}}180 million. [[NBC News]] identified the contractors, who were referred to in the report via pseudonyms, as [[Mitchell, Jessen & Associates]]. Jessen was a senior psychologist at the Defense Department who taught [[special forces]] how to resist and endure torture ([[Survival, Evasion, Resistance and Escape|SERE]]).<ref name=businessinsider>{{cite news|last1=Brodwin|first1=Erin|last2=Friedman|first2=Lauren|title=Chilling Details About The Doctors Who Enabled The Cia Torture Program|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/doctors-scientists-in-cia-torture-report-2014-12|accessdate=December 12, 2014|publisher=Business Insider|date=December 11, 2014}}</ref> The report states that neither man had prior knowledge of Al Qaeda, nor were they practised interrogators,<ref>[https://www.economist.com/news/leaders/21636035-tawdry-record-facing-up-past-best-protection-future-shock-therapy CIA torture: Shock therapy], economist.com.</ref> but they nevertheless "developed the list of enhanced interrogation techniques and personally conducted interrogations of some of the CIA's most significant detainees using those techniques. The contractors also evaluated whether the detainees' psychological state allowed for continued use of the techniques, even for some detainees they themselves were interrogating or had interrogated."
The contractors developed a list of 20 forms of torture for use against detainees, which was cut down to 10 since some forms were considered too harsh. The list included waterboarding, sleep deprivation and stress positions. [[John Rizzo]], the CIA acting general counsel who met with the contractors, described them as "sadistic and terrifying" in his book ''Company Man''.<ref name=NBC.torture-teachers>{{cite web|last1=Windrem|first1=Robert|title=CIA Paid Torture Teachers More Than $80 Million|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/cia-torture-report/cia-paid-torture-teachers-more-80-million-n264756|accessdate=December 9, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209231909/http://www.nbcnews.com/storyline/cia-torture-report/cia-paid-torture-teachers-more-80-million-n264756|archivedate=December 9, 2014}}</ref> Mitchell and Jessen were formerly SERE psychologists who have been accused of "reverse-engineering" SERE techniques for use against detainees.<ref name=PP.cia-sonsulting>{{cite web|title=Has Consulting Firm For CIA Gone MIA?|url=https://www.propublica.org/article/has-cia-consulting-firm-gone-mia-527|publisher=ProPublica|accessdate=December 9, 2014|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141209233158/https://www.propublica.org/article/has-cia-consulting-firm-gone-mia-527|archivedate=December 9, 2014}}</ref>
=== Financial aspects === According to the report, the Detention and Interrogation Program cost well over $300 million in non-personnel costs.<ref name=TheReportItself />{{rp|16}} This included funding for the CIA to construct and maintain detention facilities, including two facilities costing millions of dollars that were never used, in part due to host country political concerns. "To encourage governments to clandestinely host CIA detention sites, or to increase support for existing sites, the CIA provided millions of dollars in cash payments to foreign government officials."<ref name=TheReportItself />{{rp|16}}
The report states that in 2006, the value of the CIA's base contract with the company formed by the psychologists with all options exercised was in excess of $180 million; "the contractors received $81 million prior to the contract's termination in 2009. In 2007, the CIA provided a multi-year [[indemnification]] agreement to protect the company and its employees from legal liability arising out of the program. The CIA has since paid out more than $1 million pursuant to the agreement."<ref name=TheReportItself />{{rp|11}}
==Executive branch response == ===Response from current officials=== President [[Barack Obama]] said the report had revealed a "troubling program" and that "We will rely on all elements of our national power, including the power and example of our founding ideals. That is why I have consistently supported the declassification of today's report. No nation is perfect. But one of the strengths that makes America exceptional is our willingness to openly confront our past, face our imperfections, make changes and do better."<ref name="Fox News1" /> The Obama administration consistently worked through [[White House Chief of Staff]] [[Denis McDonough]].<ref name=NewYorkJun2015>{{cite news |last1=Bruck|first1=Connie|authorlink1=ConnieBruck|title=The Inside War: To expose torture, Dianne Feinstein fought the C.I.A.—and the White House.|url=http://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2015/06/22/the-inside-war|accessdate=July 18, 2015|work=New Yorker|date=June 22, 2015}}</ref>
[[File:John Brennan CIA official portrait.jpg|thumb|150px|right|[[John O. Brennan|John Brennan]] was the [[Director of the Central Intelligence Agency]] from March 2013 until January 2017]] CIA Director [[John O. Brennan]] agreed with the current administration's policy prohibiting enhanced interrogation techniques<ref name="CIA Response">{{cite press release |last1=Brennan |first1=John |authorlink=John O. Brennan |date=December 9, 2014 |title=Statement from Director Brennan on the SSCI Study on the Former Detention and Interrogation Program |url=https://www.cia.gov/news-information/press-releases-statements/2014-press-releases-statements/statement-from-director-brennan-on-ssci-study-on-detention-interrogation-program.html |location= |publisher=Central Intelligence Agency |accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> and admitted that the program had had "shortcomings."<ref name="Bloomberg2" /> He disagreed with the Committee's conclusion that information obtained through torture could have been obtained by other means, and said it is unknowable whether other interrogation approaches would have yielded the same information.<ref name="CIA Response" /> In supporting his views, Brennan also released a 136-page declassified version of an official CIA response and critique of the torture report written in June 2013.<ref name="CIA Response" />
The [[United States Department of Justice|Department of Justice]] (DOJ) announced that they would not be pursuing bringing any charges against anyone who might have been involved in the use of torture, noting that they "did not find any new information that they had not previously considered in reaching their determination."<ref name="DOJ Probe">{{cite web |url=http://thehill.com/policy/defense/226603-justice-department-wont-reopen-torture-probes |title=DOJ won't reopen torture probe after CIA report |last1=Hattern |first1=Julian |date=December 10, 2014 |website=[[The Hill (newspaper)|The Hill]] |accessdate=December 12, 2014}}</ref> The Department of Justice had launched two investigations overseen by [[John Durham (lawyer)|John Durham]] in 2009 that also did not result in charges.<ref name="NPRLive">{{cite web |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/12/09/justice-cia-torture/20138065/ |title=Report Says CIA Misled Congress, White House On Interrogation Program |last1=Peralta |first1=Eyder |date=December 9, 2014 |website=[[NPR]] |accessdate=December 12, 2014}}</ref> The rationale for the absence of charges has not been disclosed, but Mr. Durham did say that the full record of the possible evidence of criminal conduct and possible defenses that might be offered by any of those accused were contained in the pages of the Senate committee report that he was not going to release. Thus, it remains impossible for anyone to offer an independent evaluation of whether anyone involved was or was not guilty of criminal conduct. In response to a [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|FOIA]] lawsuit seeking access to the full report, the Obama administration argued that the rationale for not releasing all the pages of the committee report was that "disclosing them could affect the candor of law enforcement deliberations about whether to bring criminal charges."<ref name="DOJ FOIA">{{cite news |last=Savage |first=Charlie |authorlink=Charlie Savage |date=December 10, 2014 |title=U.S. Tells Court That Documents From Torture Investigation Should Remain Secret |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/11/us/politics/us-tells-court-that-documents-from-torture-investigation-should-remain-secret.html |newspaper=[[New York Times]] |accessdate=December 16, 2014 }}</ref> Given the apparent absence of those public deliberations, such a rationale seems almost incredibly obtuse, especially since, after the release of the Senate's report, several news outlets noted that "the only CIA employee connected to its interrogation program to go to prison" was [[John Kiriakou]], the whistle-blower who was "prosecuted for providing information to reporters."<ref name="ABC Kiriakou">{{cite news |last=Ross |first=Brian |authorlink=Brian Ross (journalist) |date=December 9, 2014 |title=Ex-CIA Operative Says Prison Was Punishment for Whistleblowing on Torture |url=http://abcnews.go.com/International/cia-operative-prison-punishment-whistleblowing-torture/story?id=27474359 |newspaper=[[ABC News]] |location= |accessdate=December 18, 2014 }}</ref><ref name="HuffPo Kiriakou">{{cite news |last=Levine |first=Sam |date=December 10, 2014 |title=The One Man Jailed For CIA Torture Tried To Expose It |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/10/cia-torture-prosecution_n_6298646.html |newspaper=[[The Huffington Post]] |accessdate=December 18, 2014}}</ref><ref name="Cole2015">{{cite journal |last=Cole |first=Teju |authorlink=Teju Cole |date=January 9, 2015 |title=Unmournable bodies |url=http://www.newyorker.com/culture/cultural-comment/unmournable-bodies |journal=[[The New Yorker]] |publisher=[[Condé Nast]] |accessdate=January 12, 2015 |quote="The only person in prison for the C.I.A.'s abominable torture regime is John Kiriakou, the whistle-blower."}}</ref>
===Response from former officials=== Three former CIA directors—[[George Tenet]], [[Porter Goss]] and [[Michael V. Hayden]]—as well as three former CIA deputy directors, wrote an [[op-ed]] in ''[[The Wall Street Journal]]'' in response to the release of the Senate Intelligence Committee report. They criticized the report as "a partisan attack on the agency that has done the most to protect America after the 9/11 attacks." They said that the CIA's interrogation program was invaluable to the capture of al Qaeda operatives and the disruption of al Qaeda's efforts and also stated that, contrary to the Senate Intelligence Committee's findings, "there is no doubt that information provided by the totality of detainees in CIA custody […] was essential to bringing bin Laden to justice." Additionally, they wrote that the CIA remained within the interrogation techniques authorized by the DOJ; that the CIA did not mislead the DOJ, White House or Congress; and that the threat of a "'ticking time bomb' scenario" context was critical to understanding the program.<ref>{{cite news |author1=George J. Tenet |author2=Porter J. Goss |author3=Michael V. Hayden |author4=John E. McLaughlin |author5=Albert M. Calland |author6=Stephen R. Kappes |title=Ex-CIA Directors: Interrogations Saved Lives |url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/cia-interrogations-saved-lives-1418142644 |newspaper=Wall Street Journal |date=December 10, 2014 |accessdate=December 10, 2014 }}<br />{{cite news |author=Gregory Korte |title=Former CIA directors launch rebuttal campaign |url=https://www.usatoday.com/story/news/politics/2014/12/09/torture-report-response-from-former-cia-directors/20147149/ |newspaper=USA Today |date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=December 10, 2014 }}</ref> Additionally, they established a website to defend the actions of the CIA.<ref>{{cite news |author=ZOË SCHLANGER |title=Former CIA Officials Launch CIASavedLives.com to Defend Interrogation Program |url=http://www.newsweek.com/former-officials-launch-ciasavedlivescom-defend-cias-interrogation-program-290532 |newspaper=Newsweek |date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 }}<br/>{{cite news |author=Akbar Shahid Ahmed |title=Bush Officials Step Up To Blast Torture Report Before It's Out |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/12/08/bush-officials-torture-report_n_6290106.html |newspaper=Huffington Post |date=December 8, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 }}<br/>{{cite news |author=Scott Shane |title=Political Divide About C.I.A. Torture Remains After Senate Report's Release |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/10/us/politics/obama-says-senate-report-vindicates-his-ending-of-cia-program.html |newspaper=New York Times |date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 }}<br/>{{cite news |author=Mike Allen |title=10 days to Christmas – ROLLING STONE 'RE-REPORTING' STORY -- LUKE RUSSERT gets show on new MSNBC digital stream, Shift -- RGA, DGA chiefs form bipartisan firm, 50-State LLC -- B'DAY: Donna Brazile |url=http://www.politico.com/playbook/1214/playbook16453.html |newspaper=Politico |date=December 15, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 }}<br/>{{cite news |author=Bradley Klapper |agency=Associated Press |title=CIA CHIEF JOHN BRENNAN DEFENDS AGENCY'S BUSH-ERA RECORD |url=http://7online.com/politics/cia-chief-john-brennan-defends-agencys-bush-era-record/428805/ |newspaper=WABC-TV |location=New York City |date=December 11, 2014 |accessdate=January 13, 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20150118103504/http://7online.com/politics/cia-chief-john-brennan-defends-agencys-bush-era-record/428805/ |archivedate=January 18, 2015 |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
Former [[Vice President (United States)|Vice President]] [[Dick Cheney]], who was in office during the events discussed in the report, said the report's criticisms of the CIA were "a bunch of hooey" and that harsh interrogation tactics were "absolutely, totally justified."<ref name=CheneyComments>{{cite news|newspaper=Christian Science Monitor|title=Why Dick Cheney calls the CIA torture report 'a bunch of hooey'|author=Husna Haq|date=December 10, 2014|url=http://www.csmonitor.com/USA/DC-Decoder/Decoder-Buzz/2014/1210/Why-Dick-Cheney-calls-the-CIA-torture-report-a-bunch-of-hooey}}</ref> He further said that he did not feel that the CIA misled him about the techniques used or the value of the information obtained from them, and that "if I had to do it over again, I would."<ref name=CheneyComments />
[[John Yoo]], author of the [[Torture Memos]], criticized the report as a partisan attack on American intelligence agencies and defended his belief that the CIA was legally allowed to use interrogation techniques that did not cause injury. He also stated that "if the facts on which [he] based [his] advice were wrong, [he] would be willing to change [his] opinion of the interrogation methods." In an interview in CNN's ''[[Fareed Zakaria GPS]]'', Yoo said that the harsh treatments outlined in the report could violate anti-torture laws, stating that "[i]f these things happened as described in the report [...] they were not supposed to be done." He voiced a similar opinion in a [[C-SPAN]] interview, saying that using the techniques cumulatively could violate anti-torture statute.<ref>{{cite web|title='Torture Memo' Attorney John Yoo Attacks Senate Report|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/news/asian-america/torture-memo-attorney-john-yoo-attacks-senate-report-n267241|publisher=NBC News|accessdate=December 16, 2014}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Even John Yoo has his limits|url=http://www.msnbc.com/rachel-maddow-show/even-john-yoo-has-his-limits|publisher=MSNBC|accessdate=December 15, 2014}}</ref>
== Reception == === Minority response === [[Senate Minority Leader]] [[Mitch McConnell]], Republican of Kentucky, and Senator [[Saxby Chambliss]], Republican of Georgia, opposed the study saying that they believe "it will present serious consequences for U.S. national security" and that the study was ideologically motivated. They also asserted that the program "developed significant intelligence that helped us identify and capture important al-Qa'ida terrorists, disrupt their ongoing plotting, and take down <!-- This is a direct quote! Usama is an alternative transliteration widely used by the US Government, do not change to "Osama" //-->[[Osama Bin Laden|Usama Bin Ladin]]."<ref name="Fox News1">{{cite web|last1=Herridge |first1=Catherine |last2=Pergram |first2=Chad |date=December 9, 2014|title=Senate panel releases scathing report on CIA interrogations amid security warnings|url=http://www.foxnews.com/politics/2014/12/09/senate-panel-releases-scathing-report-on-cia-interrogation-amid-warnings/|work=[[Fox News]]|accessdate=December 10, 2014}}</ref> Senators [[Marco Rubio]], Republican of Florida, and [[Jim Risch]], Republican of Idaho, stated that the report was a "partisan effort" by Democrats that "could endanger the lives of Americans overseas" and was not "serious or constructive."<ref name="Fox News1" />
Senator [[John McCain]], Republican of Arizona, himself a victim of torture [[Early life and military career of John McCain#Prisoner of war|while a prisoner of war]] in [[Vietnam War|Vietnam]],<ref>{{cite book| last=Hubbell | first=John G. | title=P.O.W.: A Definitive History of the American Prisoner-Of-War Experience in Vietnam, 1964–1973 | publisher=[[Reader's Digest Press]] | year=1976 | location=New York | isbn=0-88349-091-9}}{{page needed|date=December 2014}}</ref> said in a speech following Feinstein's presentation on the Senate floor that he supported the release of the report, and that those responsible for the interrogation policy had "stained our national honor, did much harm and little practical good."<ref name="Bloomberg2" />
=== Organizations === The [[American Civil Liberties Union]] (ACLU) argued that the attorney general should appoint a special prosecutor to conduct a full investigation, with its director [[Anthony Romero]] saying the report showed the CIA had committed [[human rights violations]].<ref name="Bloomberg2" /><ref name=BBC>{{cite news|title=CIA interrogations report sparks prosecution calls|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-30407950|publisher=BBC|date=December 10, 2014}}</ref> The [[Center for Constitutional Rights]] called for prosecutions of those responsible for the torture<ref name="CCR1">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=CCR Legal Director Says Criminal Prosecutions Must Follow Senate CIA Torture Report Findings |url=http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-legal-director-says-criminal-prosecutions-must-follow-senate-cia-torture-report-findings |location=New York |date=December 9, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014}}</ref> and joined a criminal complaint filed in Germany by the [[European Center for Constitutional and Human Rights]].<ref name="CCR2">{{cite press release |author=<!--Staff writer(s); no by-line.--> |title=CCR Joins Criminal Complaint in Germany Against Bush-Era Architects of Torture |url=http://ccrjustice.org/newsroom/press-releases/ccr-joins-criminal-complaint-germany-against-bush-era-architects-of-torture |location=Berlin |date=December 17, 2014 |accessdate=December 29, 2014}}</ref>
[[Kenneth Roth]] from [[Human Rights Watch]] called for prosecutions of senior Bush officials who authorized torture and oversaw its use. Roth stated that failure to prosecute was "more than just a failure of justice" and "means that torture effectively remains a policy option rather than a criminal offense."<ref>{{cite news|last1=Roth|first1=Kenneth|title=To deter U.S. from torturing again, those involved should be prosecuted|url=http://blogs.reuters.com/great-debate/2014/12/09/to-deter-u-s-from-torturing-again-those-involved-should-be-prosecuted/|publisher=Reuters|date=December 9, 2014}}</ref> [[Steven W. Hawkins]], the USA executive director of [[Amnesty International]], called for justice saying, "Under the [[United Nations Convention against Torture|UN convention against torture]], no exceptional circumstances whatsoever can be invoked to justify torture, and all those responsible for authorizing or carrying out torture or other ill-treatment must be fully investigated."<ref name="The Guardian">{{cite web | url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2014/dec/09/torture-cia-amnesty-international-human-rights-watch | title=CIA report: 'Torture is a crime and those responsible must be brought to justice' | publisher=The Guardian | date=December 10, 2014 | accessdate=December 12, 2014 | author=Laughland, Oliver}}</ref>
The United Nations's special rapporteur on counter-terrorism and human rights, [[Ben Emmerson]], called for the prosecution of those responsible. He said that the CIA had "commit[ed] systematic crimes and gross violations of [[international human rights law]]."<ref name="Bloomberg2" /> [[Juan E. Méndez]], the United Nations' special rapporteur on torture, said in a statement that many governments have used the American use of torture to justify their own abuses, saying "If the U.S. tortures, why can't we do it?" Mendez called the release of the report only the first step and called for "the investigation and prosecution of those who were responsible for ordering, planning or implementing the C.I.A. torture program."<ref name="Torture Fight Set Back by U.S. Failure to Prosecute, U.N. Official Says">{{cite web | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2014/12/12/world/juan-mendez-calls-for-cia-torture-prosecutions.html | title=Torture Fight Set Back by U.S. Failure to Prosecute, U.N. Official Says | publisher=The New York Times | date=December 11, 2014 | accessdate=December 11, 2014 | author=Cumming-Bruce, Nick}}</ref> Speaking on December 10, the 30th anniversary of the adoption of the [[United Nations Convention Against Torture]], Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, commended the government's release of the report saying, "Few countries will admit that their state apparatus has been practicing torture, and many continue shamelessly to deny it—even when it is well documented..." Zeid called for accountability saying, "In all countries, if someone commits murder, they are prosecuted and jailed. If they commit [[rape]] or [[armed robbery]], they are prosecuted and jailed. If they order, enable or commit torture—recognized as a serious international crime—they cannot simply be granted immunity because of political expediency. When that happens, we undermine this exceptional Convention, and – as a number of U.S. political leaders clearly acknowledged yesterday – we undermine our own claims to be civilized societies rooted in the rule of law."<ref name="United Nations Human Rights">{{cite web | url=http://www.ohchr.org/en/newsevents/pages/media.aspx | title=Zeid: Landmark U.S. and Brazil reports highlight need to eradicate torture on 30th anniversary of Convention | publisher=United Nations | date=December 10, 2014 | accessdate=December 12, 2014}}</ref>
The [[Rohr Jewish Learning Institute]] designed a course around the report, investigating the balance between national security and the civil liberties of every individual.<ref>{{cite news|last1=McManus|first1=Shani|title=Responding to terror explored|url=http://www.sun-sentinel.com/florida-jewish-journal/news/palm/fl-jjpn-school-0715-20150713-story.html|agency=South Florida Sun-Sentinel|date=July 13, 2015}}</ref>
=== International governments === [[President of Afghanistan|Afghan president]] [[Ashraf Ghani]] called the report "shocking" and said that the actions detailed in the report "violated all accepted norms of human rights in the world."<ref name=bbcnewscom>{{cite news|title=CIA 'violated human rights' – Afghan president|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-30420364|accessdate=December 12, 2014|publisher=BBC News|date=December 10, 2014}}</ref>
[[Prime Minister of Lithuania|Lithuanian Prime Minister]] [[Algirdas Butkevicius]] called on the U.S. to say whether the CIA used sites in his country to interrogate prisoners.<ref name=BBC />
Former [[President of Poland]] [[Aleksander Kwasniewski]] said that he put pressure in 2003 on American officials to end interrogations at a secret CIA prison his country hosted, saying, "I told Bush that this cooperation must end and it did end."<ref name=BBC />
[[Iranian Foreign Ministry]] spokeswoman [[Marzieh Afkham]] said the "shocking report shows violence, extremism, and secrecy as institutionalized in the US security system."<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.presstv.ir/detail/2014/12/11/389697/iran-calls-cia-torture-report-shocking/ |title=Iran calls Senate report on CIA torture 'shocking' |publisher=PressTV |date=December 11, 2014}}</ref>
The [[North Korean government]] called on the [[United Nations Security Council]] to investigate the "most brutal medieval forms" of torture practiced by the CIA at "black sites" around the world.<ref>[http://rt.com/news/214811-pyongyang-cia-un-torture/ North Korea calls on UN to investigate CIA ‘brutal medieval’ torture]. ''[[RT (TV network)|RT]].'' Retrieved December 16, 2014.</ref>
===Attempts to preserve copies of the Report===
Only a limited number of copies of the full report were made, and Human Rights workers are concerned that the CIA might succeed in destroying all copies of this report they found so embarrassing.<ref name=MiamiHerald2016-12-29/> On December 29, 2016, less than a month before the end of the Obama administration, [[District Court Judge]] [[Royce Lamberth]] ordered the preservation of the full classified report, in case it was needed during the prosecution or appeal of senior suspects during their [[Guantanamo Military Commissions]].
=== Media === *''[[Al-Ba'ath]]'' – official newspaper of the [[Arab Socialist Ba'ath Party – Syria Region]] said the U.S. "resorted to violent and ineffective measures."<ref name=Bloomberg.media-coverage /> *The report was the lead story on ''[[El País]]''.<ref name=Bloomberg.media-coverage /> *''[[Folha de S. "'''Thirty Days Hath September...'''" or "'''Thirty Days Has September...'''" is a traditional verse [[mnemonic]] used to remember the number of [[day]]s in the [[month]]s of the [[Julian calendar|Julian]] and [[Gregorian calendar]]s. It arose as an [[oral tradition]] and exists in many variants. It is currently earliest attested in English, but was and remains common throughout Europe as well. ==History== {{hatnote|Further information: [[Roman calendar]] and its [[Julian reform|Julian]] and [[Gregorian calendar|Gregorian reforms]]}} The irregularity of the lengths of the months descends from the [[Roman calendar]], which came to be adopted throughout Europe and then worldwide. The months of Rome's original [[lunar calendar]] would have varied between 29 and 30 days, depending on observations of the [[phases of the moon]].{{harvp|Mommsen|1894|loc=Vol. I, Ch. xiv}}. Reforms credited to [[Romulus]] and [[Numa Pompilius|Numa]] established a set year of twelve fixed months. Possibly under the influence of the [[Pythagoreans]] in southern Italy, Rome considered odd numbers more lucky and set the lengths of the new months to 29 and 31 days, apart from the last month [[Februarius|February]] and the [[intercalary month]] [[Mercedonius]]. Its imperfect system and political manipulation of intercalation caused it to slip greatly out of alignment with the solar year,{{harvp|Mommsen|1894|loc=Vol. V, Ch. xi}}. which was known to consist of ¼ of 1461 days (rather than 1460 days) by the time of [[Meton of Athens|Meton]] in the 5th{{nbsp}}century{{nbsp}}{{sc|bc}}. Rather than adopt a new system like the [[Egyptian calendar]], which had 12 months of 30 days each and a set, annual intercalary month of 5 days, [[Julius Caesar|Caesar]] aimed for [[Julian reform|his 46{{nbsp}}{{sc|bc}} reform]] to maintain as much continuity as possible with the old calendar.{{sfnp|Rüpke|2011|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=pThna2LDwDsC&pg=PA112 112]}} Ultimately, Mercedonius was removed, the four existing 31-day months were maintained, February was left unchanged apart from leap years, and the needful additional ten days of the year were added to the 29-day months to make them either 30 or 31 days long.{{sfnp|Rüpke|2011|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=pThna2LDwDsC&pg=PA113 113]}} By the [[Renaissance]], the irregularity of the resulting system had inspired [[Latin poetry|Latin verses]] to remember the order of long and short months. The first known published form{{citation |last=Ballew |first=Pat |contribution=On This Day in Math |contribution-url=http://pballew.blogspot.com/2015/09/on-this-day-in-math-september-1.html |url=http://pballew.blogspot.com/ |title=Pat's Blog |date=1 September 2015 }}. appeared in a 1488 edition of the Latin verses of [[Anianus (astronomer)|Anianus]]:{{citation |author=Anianus |title=Computus Metricus Manualis |location=Strasbourg }}. {{la icon}} {| |- |
{{nowrap|{{lang|la|Junius Aprilis September et ipse November}}}}
{{nowrap|{{lang|la|Dant triginta dies reliquis supadditur unus}},}}
{{nowrap|{{lang|la|De quorum numero Februarius excipiatur}}.}}
| {{gaps|{{nbsp}}|{{nbsp}}|gap=3em}} |
{{nowrap|June, April, September, and November itself}}
{{nowrap|Give thirty days, the rest add one more,}}
{{nowrap|From which number February is excepted.}}
|- |} In 2011, the Welsh author Roger Bryan discovered an older English form of the poem{{citation |last=Misstear |first=Rachael |contribution=Welsh Author Digs Deep to Find Medieval Origins of Thirty Days Hath Verse |contribution-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120206080222/http://www.walesonline.co.uk/news/need-to-read/2012/01/16/welsh-author-digs-deep-to-find-medieval-origins-of-thirty-days-hath-verse-91466-30128447 |date=16 January 2012 |title=Wales Online |location= |publisher=Media Wales }}. written at the bottom of a page of [[saints' days]] for February within a Latin manuscript in the [[British Library]]'s [[Harleian manuscripts]]. He dated the entry to 1425 ±20 years.{{sfnp|Bryan|2011}}{{citation |last=Bryan |first=Roger |date=30 October 2011 |contribution=The Oldest Rhyme in the Book |contribution-url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/article3209766.ece |title=The Times |publisher=Times Newspapers |location=London |url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/ |ref={{harvid|Bryan|2011b}} }}.{{citation |title=Today |publisher=BBC Radio 4 |location=London |contribution=Memorable Mnemonics |contribution-url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/today/hi/today/newsid_9651000/9651594.stm |date=30 November 2011 }}. {| |- |
{{nowrap|Thirti dayes hath novembir}}
{{nowrap|April june and Septembir.}}
{{nowrap|Of xxviii is but oon}}
{{nowrap|And alle the remenaunt xxx and j}}
| {{gaps|{{nbsp}}|{{nbsp}}|gap=8em}} |
{{nowrap|Thirty days have November,}}
{{nowrap|April, June, and September.}}
{{nowrap|Of 28 is but one}}
{{nowrap|And all the remnant 30 and 1.}}
|- |} The first published English version{{sfnp|Cryer|2010|loc=[https://books.google.com/books?id=QFJHqts9xXgC&pg=PA271 "Thirty Days Has September"]}} appeared in [[Richard Grafton]]'s ''Abridgment of the Chronicles of England'' in 1562{{harvp|Grafton|1562}}. as "A Rule to Know How Many Dayes Euery Moneth in the Yere Hath":{{harvp|Holland|1992|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=7uOdAwAAQBAJ&pg=PA64 64–5]}}. {| |- |
Thirty days has September
April, June and November.
All the rest have 31
Except February, it's a different one
It has 28 days clear, and 29 each leap year.
| {{gaps|{{nbsp}}|{{nbsp}}|gap=9em}} |
Thirty days have November,
April, June, and September.
February has 28 alone,
And all the rest have 31.
|- |} "September" and "November" have identical rhythm and rhyme and are thus poetically interchangeable. The early versions tended to favour November and as late as 1891 it was being given as the more common form of the rhyme in some parts of the [[United States]].{{citation |last=Ganvoort |first=A.J. |contribution=Value of Music in Public Education |contribution-url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R-MBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA389 |p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=R-MBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA392 392] |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=R-MBAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA339 |title=The Ohio Educational Monthly and the National Teacher, ''Vol. XL, No. 8'' |date=August 1891 |editor=Samuel Findley |display-editors=0 }}. It is less common now and September variants have a long history as well. A manuscript copy of the verse from {{c.|1555}}Stevins MS. runs: {| |- |
Thirty days hath September,
April, June, and November;
All the rest have thirty-one,
Excepting February alone,
And that has twenty-eight days clear
And twenty-nine in each leap year.{{sfnp|''OCDQ''|2006|p=[https://books.google.com/books?id=zLDEH2TAvwUC&pg=PT45 45]}}
|- |} Another English version from before 1574 is found in a manuscript among the Mostyn Papers held at the [[National Library of Wales]] in [[Aberystwyth]]. Variants appear throughout Europe. The typical Italian form is {| |- |
{{lang|it|Trenta giorni ha novembre
con aprile, giugno e settembre.
Di ventotto ce n'è uno.
Tutti gli altri ne han trentuno.}}{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Ek2LCwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |pp=[https://books.google.com/books?id=Ek2LCwAAQBAJ&pg=PT101 101–2] |title=Italian for Dummies |last=Onofri |first=Francesca Romana |author2=Karen Antje Moller |author3=Teresa L. Picarazzi |display-authors=1 |publisher=Berlitz |date=2012 }}.
| {{gaps|{{nbsp}}|{{nbsp}}|gap=9em}} |
Thirty days have November,
April, June, and September.
With 28 there is but one.
All the rest have thirty-one.
|- |} ==Legacy== The various forms of the poem are usually considered a [[doggerel]] [[nursery rhyme]]. In the {{c.|1601}} [[academic drama]] ''[[The Return from Parnassus|Return from Parnassus]]'', Sir Raderic's overenthusiastic appreciation of its poetry{{harvp|Anon.|1606|loc=[https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo1.ark:/13960/t5fb5mg9m;view=1up;seq=75 Act III, sc. i]}}. is of a piece with his own low level of culture and education.{{harvp|Smeaton|1905|p=xxvi}}. It has, however, also earned praise. It's been called "one of the most popular and oft-repeated verses in the English language" and "probably the only sixteenth-century poem most ordinary citizens know by heart". [[Groucho Marx]] claimed "My favorite poem is the one that starts 'Thirty Days Hath September...', because it actually means something." On the other hand, the unhelpfulness of such an involved [[mnemonic]] has been mocked, as in the early 20th-century parody "Thirty days hath September{{nbsp}}/ But all the rest I can't remember"{{citation |title=The Cincinnati Enquirer |date=20 September 1924 |location=Cincinnati |p=6 }}. It continues to be taught in schools as children learn the calendar,{{citation |contribution=How Old is 'Thirty Days Has September...' |contribution-url=http://blog.dictionary.com/monthrhyme/ |title=Blog |url=http://blog.dictionary.com/ |publisher=Dictionary.com |date=18 January 2012 }}. although others employ the [[knuckle mnemonic]] instead. "Thirty Days Hath September..." is also occasionally parodied or referenced in wider culture, such as the 1960 [[Burma-Shave]] [[jingle]] "Thirty days{{nbsp}}/ Hath September{{nbsp}}/ April{{nbsp}}/ June and the{{nbsp}}/ [[speeding|Speed offender]]".{{citation |contribution=Thirty Days |contribution-url=http://burma-shave.org/jingles/1960/thirty_days |title=Jingles |publisher=Burma-Shave.org |url=http://burma-shave.org/jingles/ |date=2005 }}. ==See also== * [[Roman calendar|Roman]], [[Julian calendar|Julian]], and [[Gregorian calendar]]s * [[Day]] & [[Month]] * [[Knuckle mnemonic]] ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ===Bibliography=== * {{citation |ref={{harvid|Smeaton|1905}} |author=[[Anonymous work|Anon.]] |title=The Return from Parnassus |editor-first=Oliphant |editor-last=Smeaton |date=1905 |publisher=J.M. Dent & Co. |location=London |url=https://archive.org/stream/returnfromparnas00smea#page/n9/mode/2up }}, a reprint of the 1606 {{citation |ref={{harvid|Anon.|1606}} |url=https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=coo1.ark:/13960/t5fb5mg9m;view=2up;seq=10;size=150 |title=The Returne from Pernassus, or, The Scourge of Simony }}. * {{citation |last=Bryan |first=Roger |title=It'll Come In Useful One Day |publisher=Llanina Books |date=2011 }}. * {{citation |last=Cryer |first=Max |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QFJHqts9xXgC&printsec=frontcover |title=Common Phrases... and the Amazing Stories Behind Them |date=2010 |location=New York |publisher=Skyhorse Publishing }}. * {{citation |last=Grafton |first=Richard |authorlink=Richard Grafton |title=Abridgement of the Chronicles of Englande |date=1562 |publisher=Richard Tottell |location=London }}. * {{citation |last=Holland |first=Norman N. |location=New York |publisher=Columbia University Press |title=The Critical I |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=7uOdAwAAQBAJ&printsec=frontcover |date=1992 }}. * {{citation |title=Oxford Concise Dictionary of Quotations, ''5th ed.'' |editor-last=Ratcliffe |editor-first=Susan |publisher=Oxford University Press |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zLDEH2TAvwUC&printsec=frontcover |date=2006 |ref={{harvid|''OCDQ''|2006}} }}. * {{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=pThna2LDwDsC&printsec=frontcover |title=The Roman Calendar from Numa to Constantine: Time, History, and the ''Fasti'' |last=Rüpke |first=Jörg |editor-last=Richardson |editor-first=David M.B. |publisher=Wiley-Blackwell |date=2011 |location=[[Malden, Massachusetts|Malden]] }}, a translation of the 1995 ''{{lang|de|Kalendar und Öffentlichkeit}}''. * {{citation |last=Mommsen |first=Theodor |title=The History of Rome |url=http://www.gutenberg.org/cache/epub/10706/pg10706-images.html |editor-last=Dickson |editor-first=William Purdie |authorlink=Theodor Mommsen |date=1894 }}, a translation of the 1861 &c. {{distinguish|Wolfgang Frank}}
'''Wolfgang Leopold Friedrich Franke''' ({{zh|c=傅吾康|p=Fù Wúkāng}}; 24 July 1912 – 6 September 2007) was a German [[Sinology|sinologist]] whose research focused on the history of the [[Ming dynasty]] and of the [[Nanyang (region)|Chinese diaspora in Southeast Asia]]. He served as Chair of Sinology at the [[University of Hamburg]] for 27 years. His father [[Otto Franke (sinologist)|Otto Franke]] had set up the chair in 1910.
==Biography== Wolfgang Franke was born in [[Hamburg]] on 24 July 1912, the fourth and youngest child of the prominent sinologist [[Otto Franke (sinologist)|Otto Franke]] and his wife Luise Niebuhr. He had a sister, as well as two brothers who died in their teens.<ref name=liew>{{cite journal |last=Liew |first=Foon Ming |title=Wolfgang Franke 1912–2007 |url=http://www.tandfonline.com/doi/pdf/10.1179/014703708788762354 |journal=Ming Studies |year=2008 |doi=10.1179/014703708788762354 |issn=0147-037X}}</ref>
Franke graduated from the Grunewald Gymnasium in [[Berlin]], and studied sinology at the [[University of Berlin]] from 1931 to 1934, but transferred in his final year to the [[University of Hamburg]]<ref name=liew/> where he studied under {{ill|Fritz Jäger|de|Fritz Jäger (Sinologe)}}. He received his doctorate degree in 1935, with a dissertation on the 1898 [[Hundred Days' Reform]] of [[Kang Youwei]].<ref name="stumpfeldt">Hans Stumpfeldt: ''[http://www.stumpfeldt.de/cg.php Zur Geschichte der China von 1980 bis 2006. Eine Dokumentation der Hamburger Sinologischen Gesellschaft (HSG)]''</ref>
After serving in the military for a year, Franke left for China, arriving in [[Shanghai]] on 18 May 1937, just before the [[Battle of Shanghai]] and the [[Second Sino-Japanese War]] began.<ref name=liew/> From 1937 to 1945 he worked as a research assistant at the German Institute (''Deutschland-Institut'') in Beijing,<ref name=liew/><ref name="stumpfeldt"/> thus avoided being drafted into the German Army during [[World War II]], during which many of his friends were killed.<ref name=liew/> In his autobiography, he writes that "I had the feelings of having lived here in my previous life and felt from the first day on at home."<ref name=liew/>
In 1941 Franke fell in love with Hu Junyin ({{zh|c=胡隽吟|w=Hu Chün-yin}}; 1910–1988), the daughter of a Chinese scholar who had studied in Germany. However, because of [[Nazi Germany]]'s [[Nuremberg Laws|prohibition]] of [[interracial marriage]], they did not marry until March 1945, near the end of World War II. They had a son and a daughter.<ref name=li>{{cite news |url=http://www.chinanews.com/cul/2012/11-27/4360438.shtml |title=“为中国着迷”的傅吾康:与胡隽吟结百年之好 |date=27 November 2012 |work=China News |language=zh |author=Li Xuetao}}</ref>
After the end of World War II, he became a professor at [[Sichuan University]] and the private [[West China Union College]] in [[Chengdu]], teaching Ming history and German history. Two years later, he became a professor of German language at [[Peking University]].<ref name=liew/><ref name=li/>
When peace was restored in post-war Germany, Franke returned to Hamburg with his family in 1950. He was appointed Chair of Sinology at the University of Hamburg, and was also Director of the Seminar for Language and Culture in China. He was the fourth holder of the Chair of Sinology and succeeded his father [[Otto Franke (sinologist)|Otto Franke]], who had set up the chair in 1910. He worked there until his retirement in 1977.<ref name=liew/><ref name="stumpfeldt"/>
After his wife died in 1988, Franke moved to [[Petaling Jaya]] near the [[University of Malaya]], where he had students and friends. He lived in Malaysia until his late eighties, when he moved to Berlin in May 2000 to live with his daughter. In his final years, when he could no longer travel, his daughter hired Chinese students to look after him, so that he could speak Chinese to someone.<ref name=liew/> He died in Berlin on 6 September 2007, at the age of 95.<ref name=liew/>
==Publications== Franke was internationally known as a China expert with research focuses on the Ming dynasty and history of the Chinese in Southeast Asia. He worked in various national and international committees on China and Asia studies and was a member of the university club of the University of Hamburg.<ref name=liew/><ref name="stumpfeldt"/>
Important works by Franke include:<ref name=liew/> *''Das Jahrhundert der chinesischen Revolution 1851-1949'' München (1958). English translation: ''A Century of Chinese Revolution 1851–1949'', Oxford (1970). *''The Reform and Abolition of the Traditional Chinese Examination System'', Harvard University Press, 1960. *''China und das Abendland'' (1962). English translation: ''China and the West'' (1962). *''An Introduction to the Sources of Ming History'' (1968). Chinese translation: 明代史籍彙考引言 (1970). *''China-Handbuch'' (''China Handbook'') (1974).
He also wrote a two-volume autobiography ''Im Banne Chinas'' (''Under the Spell of China''; part 1: 1912–1950 and part 2: 1950–1998). In addition, from the mid-1960s onwards, he dealt intensively with the scholars in Southeast Asia and collected epigraphic material. The results of his research were published in English in several volumes for Malaysia 1983–87, Indonesia 1997 and Thailand 1998.<ref name=liew/>
